body:
Ah, yes. We need to update the build file.
On Feb 27, 2016 14:53, "Dragos Ionescu" notifications@github.com wrote:

> In my bazel project I include grpc (tag = "release-0_13_0") and protobuf
> (tag = "v3.0.0-beta-2") via new_git_repository. Trying to compile
> greeter_async_client, I got the error below. Adding linkopts "-ldl" to the
> grpc rule seems to fix the problem. Is this an issue with my specific
> configuration or is it a BUILD rule bug?
> 
> ERROR: /home/dragos/trunk/examples/rpc/helloworld/BUILD:31:1: Linking of
> rule '//examples/rpc/helloworld:greeter_async_client' failed: gcc failed:
> error executing command
> (cd
> /home/dragos/.cache/bazel/_bazel_dragos/d6d537d024f15fe49a1f0b1df0136b24/trunk
> && \
> exec env - \
> /usr/bin/gcc -o
> bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/examples/rpc/helloworld/greeter_async_client
> -pthread -B/usr/bin/ -Wl,-z,relro,-z,now -no-canonical-prefixes
> -pass-exit-codes '-Wl,--build-id=md5' '-Wl,--hash-style=gnu' -Wl,-S
> -Wl,@bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/examples/rpc/helloworld/greeter_async_client-2.params):
> gcc failed: error executing command
> (cd
> /home/dragos/.cache/bazel/_bazel_dragos/d6d537d024f15fe49a1f0b1df0136b24/trunk
> && \
> exec env - \
> /usr/bin/gcc -o
> bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/examples/rpc/helloworld/greeter_async_client
> -pthread -B/usr/bin/ -Wl,-z,relro,-z,now -no-canonical-prefixes
> -pass-exit-codes '-Wl,--build-id=md5' '-Wl,--hash-style=gnu' -Wl,-S
> -Wl,@bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/examples/rpc/helloworld/greeter_async_client-2.params).
> bazel-out/local_linux-fastbuild/bin/external/grpc/libgrpc.a(env_linux.pic.o):
> In function gpr_getenv':
> env_linux.c:(.text+0x49): undefined reference todlsym'
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/grpc/grpc/issues/5472.
Odd... you should need to do -DGPR_BACKWARDS_COMPATIBILITY_MODE to get that code path looking at the code here: https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/release-0_13/src/core/support/env_linux.c
I think this is stale. If it is not, it'll be caught and fixed with #1951
